'''ABC FlowCharter''' is a [[flowchart]] program originally from [[Micrografx]], Inc. The [[trademark]] for this software was filed on August 25, 1989, and registered January 1991.<ref name=trademark/> It is also known as Micrografx FlowCharter and iGrafx FlowCharter.<ref name=stolovitch_pershing_keeps2006/>
Version 4.0 of ABC FlowCharter was released in 1995. It integrated the ABC ToolKit software from Micrografx and included new diagramming tools and templates. The software added intelligent line routing, which automatically routed connecting lines around other shapes.<ref name=iw17_8_30/> This software was compatible with an IBM 386 computer with Windows 3.1, 5 Mb of RAM a VGA monitor and required 21 Mb of hard disk space.<ref name=avery_zabel1997/>
Following the acquisition of Micrografx by the Canadian company [[Corel]] in 2001, this software was then maintained by the separate business unit [[iGrafx]], formed in 2003. The software package was renamed to "iGrafx FlowCharter 2003".<ref name=tonchia_tramontano2004/> {{as of|2015}}, the currently available version of this software package is "iGrafx FlowCharter 2013". It is compatible with Windows XP, Windows Vista and Windows 7.<ref name=faq/>

[[Accent (sociolinguistics)|Accent]]s are the distinctive variations in the pronunciation of a language. They can be native or foreign, local or national and can provide information about a person’s geographical [[locality (settlement)|locality]], [[socio-economic status]] and [[ethnicity]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Labov|first=W.|title=The social stratification of English in New York City|year=2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge [UK]|isbn=978-0-521-82122-3|edition=2nd}}</ref> The '''perception of accents''' is normal within any given group of language users and involves the categorisation of speakers into [[social groups]] and entails judgments about the accented speaker, including their status<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ross|first=A.|title=Linguistic class-indicators in present-day English|journal=Neuphilologische Mitteilungen|year=1954|volume=16|pages=171–185}}</ref> and [[personality]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dailey|first=R. M.|author2=Giles, Howard|author3= Jansma, Laura L.|title=Language attitudes in an Anglo-Hispanic context: the role of the linguistic landscape|journal=Language & Communication|year=2005|volume=25|issue=1|pages=27–38|doi=10.1016/j.langcom.2004.04.004}}</ref> Accents can significantly alter the perception of an individual or an entire group, which is an important fact considering that the frequency that people with different accents are encountering one another is increasing, partially due to inexpensive international travel and [[social media]]. As well as affecting judgments, accents also affect key [[Cognition|cognitive processes]] (e.g., [[memory]]) that are involved in a myriad of daily activities. The development of accent perception occurs in early childhood. Consequently, from a young age accents influence our perception of other people, decisions we make about when and how to interact with others, and, in reciprocal fashion, how other people perceive us. A better understanding of the role accents play in our (often inaccurate) appraisal of individuals and groups, may facilitate greater acceptance of people different from ourselves and lessen discriminatory attitudes and behavior.<sup>[subjective / citations?[</sup>
== Social identity theory of accents ==
[[Social identity theory]] is a theory that describes intergroup behaviour based on group membership. Markers of group membership can be arbitrary, e.g., coloured vests, a flip of a coin, etc., or non-arbitrary, e.g., gender, language, race, etc.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lindzey|first=D. T.|author2=Gilbert, S. T.|author3= Fiske, G.|title=The handbook of social psychology|year=1998|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=Boston, Massachusetts |isbn=0-19-521376-9|pages=357–411|edition=4th}}</ref> Accent is a non-arbitrary marker for group membership that is potentially more salient than most other non-arbitrary markers such as race<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kurzban|first=R.|author2=Tooby, J.|author3= Cosmides, L.|title=Can race be erased? Coalitional computation and social categorization|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|year=2001|volume=98|issue=26|pages=15387–15392|doi=10.1073/pnas.251541498|pmid=11742078|pmc=65039}}</ref> and visual cues in general.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Rakić | first = T. |author2= Steffens, M. C.|author3= Mummendey, A. | title = Blinded by the accent! The minor role of looks in ethnic categorization | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
| year = 2011 | volume = 100 | issue = 1 | pages = 16–29 | doi = 10.1037/a0021522 | pmid=21038973 }}</ref> One component of social identity theory states that members of the same group will treat and judge other members of their group ([[in-group]] members) preferentially compared to those who are not in their group ([[Ingroups and outgroups|out-group]] members).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tajfel|first=H.|author2=Billig, M. G.|author3= Bundy, R. P.|author4= Flament, C.|title=Social categorization and intergroup behaviour|journal=European Journal of Social Psychology|year=1971|volume=1|issue=2|pages=149–178|doi=10.1002/ejsp.2420010202}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Billig|first=M.|author2=Tajfel, H.|title=Social categorization and similarity in intergroup behaviour|journal=European Journal of Social Psychology|year=1973|volume=3|issue=1|pages=27–52|doi=10.1002/ejsp.2420030103}}</ref> This phenomenon is called [[in-group bias]] and when applied to accents is called the own-accent bias. There are many examples of the discrimination of out-groups based on language, e.g., the banning of the [[German language in the United States#Persecution during World War I|public speaking of German]] in the [[United States]] during [[World War I]] and the [[Al-Anfal Campaign]], however, there are also examples of discrimination based on accent. Some of these instances date back many several millennia, for example, in the [[Bible]] in Judges 12:5-6 the following quote depicting the mass-killing of a people based on their accent appears:
:“The Gileadites captured the fords of the Jordan leading to Ephraim, and whenever a survivor of Ephraim said, “Let me cross over,” the men of Gilead asked him, “Are you an Ephraimite?” If he replied, “No,” they said, “All right, say ‘Shibboleth.’” If he said, “Sibboleth,” because he could not pronounce the word correctly, they seized him and killed him at the fords of the Jordan. Forty-two thousand Ephraimites were killed at that time.”
Whereas some are more recent, for example, in his play [[Pygmalion (play)|Pygmalion]] [[George Bernard Shaw]] famously recognised the disparities of accent (even in a native context) when he wrote:
:“It is impossible for an Englishman to open his mouth without making some other Englishman hate or despise him”.<ref>{{cite book|last=Shaw|first=B.|title=Pygmalion : a romance in five acts : definitive text|year=2008|publisher=Methuen Drama|location=London|isbn=9780713679977}}</ref>
== Evolutionary underpinnings of the own-accent bias ==
Accents function as markers of social group membership broadcasting information about individuals' in-group/out-group status. However, unlike other seemingly more conspicuous non-arbitrary markers (e.g., race), the accent an individual has is not outwardly obvious to a casual observer unless the individual speaks and is within hearing range of the observer. This begs the question of how such an easily hidden characteristic became a marker of group membership in the first place. One predominant account suggests an answer to this conundrum lies in [[Evolutionary history of life|evolutionary history]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Baker|first=M. C.|title=The atoms of language.|year=2001|publisher=Basic Books|location=New York, USA|isbn=978-0465005222}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Henrich|first=N.|title=Why humans cooperate a cultural and evolutionary explanation|year=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=978-0195314236|author2=Henrich, J.}}</ref> In modern societies people of many different racial backgrounds live together, which provides modern humans with the chance to experience a wide range of races and racial characteristics (e.g., different coloured skin).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Messick|first=D. M.|author2=Mackie, D. M.|title=Intergroup relations|journal=Annual Review of Psychology|year=1989|volume=40|issue=1|pages=45–81|doi=10.1146/annurev.ps.40.020189.000401}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Stangor|first=C.|author2=Lynch, L.|author3= Duan, C.|author4= Glas, B.|title=Categorization of individuals on the basis of multiple social features|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|year=1992|volume=62|issue=2|pages=207–218|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.62.2.207}}</ref> However, in early societies neighbouring communities could not travel far except by walking, thus they were likely to look similar.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cosmides|first=L.|author2=Tooby, J.|author3= Kurzban, R.|title=Perceptions of race|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|year=2003|volume=7|issue=4|pages=173–179|doi=10.1016/S1364-6613(03)00057-3|pmid=12691766}}</ref> As such, a [[natural selection]] pressure may have existed that favoured social attention to accents, which functioned as an [[Signalling theory#Honest signals|honesty signal]] (i.e., an honest signal of an individual's group membership), so individuals could easily identify in-group members from the potential threat of out-group members.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cohen|first=E.|title=The evolution of tag-based cooperation in humans|journal=Current Anthropology|year=2012|volume=53|issue=5|pages=588–616|doi=10.1086/667654}}</ref> In comparison, the [[Evolutionary pressure|selection pressure]] to socially attend to race was less relevant.<ref name="Accent Trumps Race in Guiding Children's Social Preferences">{{cite journal|last=Kinzler|first=K. D.|author2=Shutts, K.|author3= DeJesus, J.|author4= Spelke, E. S.|title=Accent trumps race in guiding children's social preferences|journal=Social Cognition|year=2009|volume=27|issue=4|pages=623–634|doi=10.1521/soco.2009.27.4.623|pmid=21603154|pmc=3096936}}</ref>
== Theories of own-accent bias ==
The ''own-accent bias'' is the inclination toward, and more positive judgement of, individuals with the same accent as yourself compared to those with a different accent. There are two main theories that attempt to explain this bias: affective processing and prototype representation.
=== Affective processing ===
The affective processing approach proposes that the positive-bias exhibited for others who speak with an own-accent is produced by a (potentially [[Unconscious mind|unconscious]]) [[emotion]]al reaction. Put simply, people like others who have the same accent as themselves for that precise reason; they like it. This theory has developed, and draws support, from [[neuroscience|neuroscientific]] research investigating affective [[prosody (linguistics)|prosody]] (a key component underlying accent) and vocal emotion, which has found activation (predominantly in the right [[Cerebral hemisphere|hemisphere]]) in important brain regions associated with the processing of emotion. These regions include: * [[middle temporal gyrus|Mid]] and [[superior temporal gyrus|superior]] [[transverse temporal gyrus|temporal gyri]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=R. L. C.|author2=Elliott, R.|author3= Barry, M.|author4= Cruttenden, A.|author5= Woodruff, P. W. R.|title=The neural response to emotional prosody, as revealed by functional magnetic resonance imaging|journal=Neuropsychologia|year=2003|volume=41|issue=10|pages=1410–1421|doi=10.1016/S0028-3932(03)00017-4|pmid=12757912}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Leitman|first=D. I.|author2=Wolf, D. H.|author3= Ragland, J. D. |author4=Laukka, P. |author5=Loughead, J. |author6=Valdez, J. N. |author7=Gur, G. C.|title="It's not what you say, but how you say it": A reciprocal temporo-frontal network for affective prosody|journal=Frontiers in Human Neuroscience|year=2010|volume=4|pages=4–19|doi=10.3389/fnhum.2010.00019}}</ref> * [[Insular cortex|Insulae]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Klasen|first=M.|author2=Kenworthy, C. A.|author3= Mathiak, K. A.|author4= Kircher, T. T. J.|author5= Mathiak, K.|title=Supramodal Representation of Emotions|journal=Journal of Neuroscience|year=2011|volume=31|issue=38|pages=13635–13643|doi=10.1523/jneurosci.2833-11.2011|pmid=21940454}}</ref><ref name="Towards a fronto-temporal neural network for the decoding of angry vocal expressions">{{cite journal|last=Frühholz|first=S.|author2=Grandjean, D.|title=Towards a fronto-temporal neural network for the decoding of angry vocal expressions|journal=NeuroImage|year=2012|volume=62|issue=3|pages=1658–1666|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2012.06.015|pmid=22721630}}</ref> * [[Inferior frontal gyrus]]<ref name="Towards a fronto-temporal neural network for the decoding of angry vocal expressions" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Ethofer|first=T.|author2=Bretscher, J.|author3= Gschwind, M.|author4= Kreifelts, B.|author5= Wildgruber, D.|author6= Vuilleumier, P.|title=Emotional voice areas: Anatomic location, functional properties, and structural connections revealed by combined fMRI/DTI|journal=Cerebral Cortex|year=2011|volume=22|issue=1|pages=191–200|doi=10.1093/cercor/bhr113|pmid=21625012}}</ref> * [[Basal ganglia]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pell|first=M. D.|author2=Leonard, C. L.|title=Processing emotional tone from speech in Parkinson's disease: A role for the basal ganglia|journal=Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience|year=2003|volume=3|issue=4|pages=275–288|doi=10.3758/cabn.3.4.275}}</ref> * [[Amygdalae]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Klasen|first=M.|author2=Kenworthy, C. A.|author3= Mathiak, K. A.|author4= Kircher, T. T. J.|author5= Mathiak, K.|title=Supramodal representation of emotions|journal=Journal of Neuroscience|year=2011|volume=31|issue=38|pages=13635–13643|doi=10.1523/jneurosci.2833-11.2011|pmid=21940454}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Frühholz|first=S.|author2=Grandjean, D.|title=Amygdala subregions differentially respond and rapidly adapt to threatening voices|journal=Cortex|year=2013|volume=49|issue=5|pages=1394–1403|doi=10.1016/j.cortex.2012.08.003|pmid=22938844}}</ref> Additional to the processing of memory and emotion, the amygdalae have important roles as “relevance detectors" for the discernment of relevant social information.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sander|first=D.|author2=Grafman, J.|author3= Zalla, T.|title=The Human Amygdala: An Evolved System for Relevance Detection|journal=Reviews in the Neurosciences|year=2003|volume=14|issue=4|pages=303–316|doi=10.1515/revneuro.2003.14.4.303|pmid=14640318}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Schirmer|first=A.|author2=Escoffier, N.|author3= Zysset, S.|author4= Koester, D.|author5= Striano, T.|author6= Friederici, A. D.|title=When vocal processing gets emotional: On the role of social orientation in relevance detection by the human amygdala|journal=NeuroImage|year=2008|volume=40|issue=3|pages=1402–1410|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2008.01.018|pmid=18299209}}</ref> Therefore, these brain regions that deal with social relevance and vocal emotion are probable candidates for a neural network concerning accent-based group membership that would drive the affective processing of accents.
=== Prototype representation ===
The prototype representation approach stems from theories developed in the [[linguistics]] and [[cognitive psychology]] domains. It proposes that there are “prototypes” (i.e., internal representations) stored in the brain, which incoming information from the senses is compared against to facilitate categorisation.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rosch|first=E.|title=Natural categories|journal=Cognitive Psychology|year=1973|volume=4|issue=3|pages=328–350|doi=10.1016/0010-0285(73)90017-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Valentine|first=T.|title=A unified account of the effects of distinctiveness, inversion, and race in face recognition|journal=The Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology Section A|year=1991|volume=43|issue=2|pages=161–204|doi=10.1080/14640749108400966}}</ref> Therefore, the own-accent bias is due to the fact that own-accents are similar to the prototype of "accent" hence are processed and categorised more easily than those other-accents that are dissimilar. This idea is supported by research showing that the further away a voice is from the average, (which is assumed to be a good representation of the internal prototype of accent) the more distinctive and less attractive it is rated, and the more activity is produced in the [[temporal voice areas]] (areas of the brain that deal with voice perception and accents).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Belin|first=P.|author2=Zatorre, R. J.|title='What', 'where' and 'how' in auditory cortex [letter to the editor]|journal=Nature Neuroscience|year=2000|volume=3|issue=10|pages=965–966|doi=10.1038/79890|pmid=11017161}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bestelmeyer|first=P. E. G.|author2=Belin, P.|author3= Grosbras, M-H.|title=Right temporal TMS impairs voice detection|journal=Current Biology|year=2011|volume=21|issue=20|pages=R838–R839|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2011.08.046|pmid=22032183}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bestelmeyer|first=P. E. G.|author2=Latinus, M.|author3= Bruckert, L.|author4= Rouger, J.|author5= Crabbe, F.|author6= Belin, P.|title=Implicitly perceived vocal attractiveness modulates prefrontal cortex activity|journal=Cerebral Cortex|year=2011|volume=22|issue=6|pages=1263–1270|doi=10.1093/cercor/bhr204|pmid=21828348}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bruckert|first=L.|author2=Bestelmeyer, P. E. G.|author3= Latinus, M. |author4=Rouger, J. |author5=Charest, I. |author6=Rousselet, G. A. |author7=Belin, P.|title=Vocal attractiveness increases by averaging|journal=Current Biology|year=2010|volume=20|issue=2|pages=116–120|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2009.11.034|pmid=20129047}}</ref>
== Research into accent perception ==
Recent research has investigated the effects of accent on [[earwitness memory]] (similar to [[eyewitness memory]] but based on what a person heard rather than saw). The study showed that ear-witnesses were more likely to mistake offenders with a different accent than an own-accent, and that their judgements were less confident in reporting other-accent offenders compared to those with their own-accent.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stevenage|first=S. V.|author2=Clarke, G.|author3= McNeill, A.|title=The "other-accent" effect in voice recognition|journal=Journal of Cognitive Psychology|year=2012|volume=24|issue=6|pages=647–653|doi=10.1080/20445911.2012.675321}}</ref> The authors of the study present similarities between the own-accent bias and the [[Cross-race effect|own-race bias]], which states that faces are more easily recognised by people of the same race (own-race) because those people have more experience (higher expertise) with them compared to faces of different races (other-race).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chiroro|first=P.|author2=Valentine, T.|title=An investigation of the contact hypothesis of the own-race bias in face recognition|journal=The Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology Section A|year=1995|volume=48|issue=4|pages=879–894|doi=10.1080/14640749508401421}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Michel|first=C.|author2=Caldara, R.|author3= Rossion, B.|title=Same-race faces are perceived more holistically than other-race faces|journal=Visual Cognition|year=2006|volume=14|issue=1|pages=55–73|doi=10.1080/13506280500158761}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Tanaka|first=J. W.|author2=Kiefer, M.|author3= Bukach, C. M.|title=A holistic account of the own-race effect in face recognition: evidence from a cross-cultural study|journal=Cognition|year=2004|volume=93|issue=1|pages=B1–B9|doi=10.1016/j.cognition.2003.09.011|pmid=15110726}}</ref> This is similar to the prototype representation theory of the own-accent bias (see above). Another study investigated the effects of teacher-accent on student learning. This research found that students recalled more information from lectures with teachers who had their own-accent and rated the own-accent teachers more favourably compared to those with an other-accent.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gill|first=M. M.|title=Accent and stereotypes: Their effect on perceptions of teachers and lecture comprehension|journal=Journal of Applied Communication Research|year=1994|volume=22|issue=4|pages=348–361|doi=10.1080/00909889409365409}}</ref> Additionally, research focussing on the development of the own-accent bias in infants and children has shown that children are not only consistently able to differentiate between foreign- and native-accents<ref>{{cite journal|last=Floccia|first=C.|author2=Butler, J.|author3= Girard, F.|author4= Goslin, J.|title=Categorization of regional and foreign accent in 5- to 7-year-old British children|journal=International Journal of Behavioral Development|year=2009|volume=33|issue=4|pages=366–375|doi=10.1177/0165025409103871}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Girard|first=F.|author2=Floccia, C.|author3= Goslin, J.|title=Perception and awareness of accents in young children|journal=British Journal of Developmental Psychology|year=2008|volume=26|issue=3|pages=409–433|doi=10.1348/026151007X251712}}</ref> but that infants and children prefer individuals who have a native accent compared to a foreign one, leading them to change their behaviour based on a speakers accent (e.g., accepting a toy off a native-accented speaker rather than a foreign-accented speaker).<ref name="Accent Trumps Race in Guiding Children's Social Preferences" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Kinzler|first=K. D.|author2=Dupoux, E.|author3= Spelke, E. S.|title=The native language of social cognition|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|year=2007|volume=104|issue=30|pages=12577–12580|doi=10.1073/pnas.0705345104|pmc=1941511}}</ref>

'''Agency''' (also referred to as '''free agency''' or '''moral agency'''), in [[Beliefs and practices of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|Latter-day Saint theology]], is "the privilege of choice which was introduced by God the Eternal Father to all of his spirit children in the premortal state".<ref name="stapley"/> Mortal life is viewed as a test of faith, where our choices are central to the [[Plan of salvation (Latter Day Saints)|plan of salvation]] in Mormon teaching. "It was essential for their eternal progression that they be subjected to the influences of both good and evil".<ref name="stapley" /> Mormons believe that Lucifer presented an alternative plan, which resulted in a [[war in heaven]], with Lucifer being cast out of heaven and becoming Satan.<ref>{{lds|Abraham |abr|3|24|28}}; {{lds|Revelation|rev|12|7|9}}; {{lds|Isaiah|isa|14|12|15}}.</ref>
Mormons believe that all individuals have the ability to differentiate between good and evil<ref>See {{lds|Moroni|moro|7|18|19}}; {{lds|Moroni|moro|8|9|10}}; {{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|88|6|7}}.</ref> and that Satan and his followers are not able to tempt people beyond the point where they can resist.<ref>See {{lds|1 Corinthians|1-cor|10|13}}; {{lds|Alma|alma|13|28}}.</ref> This implies that mortals can be held accountable for their actions;<ref name="Self-Accountability and Human Progress"/> mortals will be judged by God based on a combination of one's faith and works (with salvation coming only through the power, mercy, and grace of Jesus Christ).<ref name="Faith and Good Works"/>
==Pre-Earth life== {{See also|Pre-mortal existence#Latter Day Saints}} A major difference between the beliefs of Latter-day Saints and many other Christians involves the belief of a life before mortality, referred to as the pre-earth life, pre-mortal life, or [[pre-existence]]. Latter-day Saints believe that before the earth was created, all mankind lived as spirit children of God.<ref>{{lds|Hebrews|heb|12|9}}</ref> Here, God nurtured, taught and provided means for their development. This preparation would allow them to later become the men and women of Earth, to be further educated and tested in the schoolhouse of mortality in order to return to God's presence and become like him. Thus, the pre-existent life is believed to have been a period of unknown length of progression, and schooling. Mormons believe that there came a time when we could not progress further without being born into a body and experiencing earthly life.<ref>{{citation |url= http://www.lds.org/ensign/2002/01/the-choice-that-began-mortality |title= The Choice That Began Mortality |first= Jess L. |last= Christensen |date=January 2002 |journal= [[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] }}</ref>
According to Mormon beliefs, God proposed a plan whereby further progression could take place, a [[plan of salvation]]. Because agency would allow all people to fall in sin, a savior was necessary to [[Atonement in Christianity|atone]] for the sins of each person so that they could return to live with their Father in Heaven. [[Jesus]] volunteered to follow the plan as outlined, which preserved agency, accountability for action, and the necessary result that some of Heavenly Father's children would never to return to Heavenly Father as a consequence of sin. The second volunteer, [[Lucifer]], attempted to amend the plan by proposing that all mankind would return to Heavenly Father despite their sins—essentially defeating agency and the divine principle of accountability for action. God the Father chose the plan that he proposed with Jesus as the Savior. Lucifer and his followers rebelled against this plan and were eventually cast out of heaven. Lucifer became [[Satan]].<ref>Much of this is discussed in {{lds|Abraham|abr|3|22|28}}. Latter-day Saints also believe {{lds|Isaiah|isa|14|12|15}} refers to this incident.</ref>
===Foreordination=== Mormons believe that another aspect of agency occurred during the pre-mortal life. Some of the spirit children of God exercised their agency and conformed to God's law and became "noble and great". This doctrine is called "[[Predestination|foreordination]]". God foreordained some of these spirits to particular stations in life in order to advance his plan to lead humanity back to his presence.<ref>{{lds|Abraham|abr|22|23}}</ref>
Mormons believe that these foreordinations were not unalterable decrees, but rather callings from God for man to perform specific missions in mortality. Even these who were foreordained for greatness could fall and transgress the laws of God. Therefore, mortality is simply a state wherein progression and testing is continued from what began in the pre-existence.
Mormon doctrine states that God's plan includes the foreordination of prophets and teachers who have gifts and callings among men to teach and re-teach correct principles so that agency can be used wisely.<ref>{{lds|Jeremiah|jer|1|5}}</ref> God's plan includes the important role of parents to teach their children the path of righteousness and happiness,<ref>{{lds|Deuteronomy|deut|6|7}}</ref> and the blessing of the holy scriptures to give a foundation of gospel knowledge, including the knowledge of the saving role of Jesus Christ and the importance of ordinances and covenants of the gospel.
==Earth life== In essence, agency is the ability to make choices for oneself, as well as the ability to learn the difference between right and wrong and to make ethical and moral decisions.<ref>{{citation |url= http://www.lds.org/study/topics/agency |title= Gospel Topics: Agency |work= lds.org |publisher= LDS Church }}</ref>
[[David O. McKay]], a [[President of the Church (LDS Church)|President of the Church]], stated, "It is the purpose of the Lord that man become like him. In order for man to achieve this it was necessary for the Creator first to make him free."<ref>''Conference Report'', April 1950, 32. As quoted in {{citation|url=http://institute.lds.org/content/languages/english/Institute%20of%20Religion%20Materials/Student%20Manuals/Religion%20430-431,%20Doctrines%20of%20the%20Gospel%20Student%20Manual~eng.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514133833/http://institute.lds.org/content/languages/english/Institute%20of%20Religion%20Materials/Student%20Manuals/Religion%20430-431,%20Doctrines%20of%20the%20Gospel%20Student%20Manual~eng.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-05-14 |chapter=Chapter 11: The Agency of Man |title=Doctrines of the Gospel: Student Manual, Religion 430 and 431 |publisher=[[Institute of Religion|Institute]] program, [[Church Educational System]], LDS Church |edition=Second |year=2004 }}</ref> Without agency, mortality would be useless. Men are ultimately responsible for their own destiny, through their faith and obedience to the commandments of God. "Free agency" therefore should not be interpreted to mean that actions are without consequences; "free" means that it is a gift from God and consequences must necessarily come as a result of choices made. Free agency and accountability are complementary and cannot be separated.
This principle holds that it is wrong to deny someone of his or her free agency unless they have abused it to infringe against the agency of another, as it would bind a person from their own choices. Such offenses logically include crimes such as [[murder]], [[rape]] and [[slavery]]. Furthermore, a person who prevents an individual from doing what they have been commanded to do (e.g., force them to do something they believe is wrong) will be held responsible for any offense.<ref>{{cite book |first= James E. |last= Talmage |authorlink= James E. Talmage |origyear= 1899 |year= 1981 |title= [[Articles of Faith (Talmage)|Articles of Faith]] |location= Salt Lake City, Utah |publisher= Deseret Book |page= {{Page needed|date=February 2012}} |isbn= 0-87747-838-4 |oclc= 6708594 }}</ref>
Throughout the 20th century, church leaders often equated governments led by dictatorships as being under the influence and control of Satan.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} For example, [[apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostle]] [[Ezra Taft Benson]] often spoke of the "evil" communist or socialist movements that threatened the free agency of mankind: "it is realized that communism is turning out to be the earthly image of the plan which Satan presented in the preexistence. The whole program of socialistic communism is essentially a war against God and the plan of salvation—the very plan which we fought to uphold during 'the war in heaven.'"<ref>{{cite book |first= Ezra Taft |last= Benson |authorlink= Ezra Taft Benson |year= 1974 |chapter= The American Heritage of Freedom |title= God, Family, Country: Our Three Great Loyalties |location= Salt Lake City |publisher= [[Deseret Book]] |page= 356 |oclc= 1130226 }}</ref> Other leaders contradicted these statements, often pointing to the church's belief in the "[https://www.lds.org/scriptures/gs/consecrate-law-of-consecration Law of Consecration]" which is a form of socialism practiced by early church members in which all property was held in common and distributed by church leaders based on the needs of each individual. The church is [http://www.mormonnewsroom.org/official-statement/political-neutrality officially politically neutral] and today church members around the world subscribe to a variety of political beliefs including communism and socialism.
Mormon doctrine teaches that many men and women since the beginning of mortal time have used their agency unwisely, limiting their own progress and their opportunity to receive light and knowledge. Beginning with [[Cain and Abel|Cain]], some have used their agency to inflict harm, abuse, tyranny, slavery, or death upon others, contrary to the will and commandments of God.
The fact that God allows these actions does not mean that He condones them. LDS doctrine holds that agency is an eternal principle, and that God has provided the way through the atonement of Jesus Christ whereby men and women can repent of their wrongful acts of commission or of omission, and come back into the path of receiving further light and knowledge through making right choices. The atonement of Christ and the plan of compassion among men also provides a way whereby those who have been harmed by the sinful actions of others may be healed in a spiritual sense, although this may take great patience and long-suffering, and often requires the help of others.
[[Pearl of Great Price (Mormonism)|The Pearl of Great Price]], one of the scriptures of the LDS church, states that Satan, the great deceiver, sought during premortal life to destroy the agency of man,<ref>{{lds|Moses|moses|4|3}}</ref> and that he continues to seek to enslave men, women and children in whatever ways that he can in this world, to "lead them captive at his will."<ref>{{lds|Moses|moses|4|4}}</ref> LDS doctrine teaches that whatever leads in this world to enslavement, addiction, or forced behavior is ultimately instigated by Satan. God allows these conditions because of the agency he has given to man, but He expects men to overcome evil by doing good among the society in which they live. God holds men and women responsible and accountable in relation to the light and knowledge they have. Every person born into the world is given the light of Christ, also called conscience, to guide each person in choosing good from evil.<ref>{{lds|Moroni|moro|7|18|19}}</ref>
LDS doctrine also holds that whenever gospel knowledge has been lost or limited among portions of mankind, this has come about because of the unrighteousness of the people and their leaders, as described by the prophet Isaiah in the Bible.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
LDS leaders teach that family and societal relationships are a part of mortal life for many purposes, including the need to learn to show love, acceptance, and compassion in ways that continue to allow agency. They teach that unrighteous dominion is never acceptable to God, and that with the agency given to men is the expectation that when they marry, they will treat their wife and children with love, respect, tenderness, and material and emotional support. LDS leaders teach that men should treat women as equal partners in all decisions in the family.<ref>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|121|34|46}}</ref>
==="Free" agency===
The term free agency is commonly used, and has traditionally been interpreted as meaning that individuals have the ability to choose their actions freely. Many leaders of the LDS Church have pointed out that the term "free agency" should not be interpreted to mean that agency does not have consequences, but rather that agency is fraught with risk and choices (the result of the exercise of agency) determine eternal destination. Some church manuals avoid the term "free agency" and instead refer simply "agency."<ref>{{citation |chapter= Lesson 2: Agency: The Power to Choose |chapter-url= http://www.lds.org/manual/preparing-for-exaltation-teachers-manual/lesson-2-agency-the-power-to-choose |title= Preparing for Exaltation: Teacher’s Manual |year= 1998 |publisher= LDS Church |quote= Note that although the term 'free agency' is often used, the correct, scriptural term is simply 'agency'. }}</ref> Some church leaders favor the term "moral agency".<ref>E.g., {{citation |first= Dallin H. |last= Oaks |authorlink= Dallin H. Oaks |url= http://www.lds.org/liahona/2000/03/weightier-matters |title= Weightier Matters |journal= [[Liahona (magazine)|Liahona]] |date=March 2000 |page= 15 }}.</ref>
===Adam and Eve=== {{see also|Fall of man}} It is said that [[Adam and Eve (LDS Church)|Adam and Eve]] were the first of God’s children to come to Earth. They were created in God’s image, with bodies of flesh and bones. God placed them in the Garden of Eden. Here they did not remember their former existence though they were still able to enjoy God's presence and could have lived forever.
As it is believed the Heavenly Father has blessed all of His children with the freedom to choose, Adam and Eve were given agency to make their own choices on the earth. He commanded them not to eat the forbidden fruit, or the fruit of the tree of knowledge of good and evil, warning that such would result in death. Obeying this commandment meant they could remain in the garden forever, but they could not progress by experiencing opposition in mortality and would remain innocent; they could not know joy because they could not experience sorrow and pain. Thus, as a part of the plan, Satan was allowed to tempt Adam and Eve to eat the forbidden fruit and they chose to do so. As a consequence, they were separated from God's presence physically and spiritually. Adam and Eve then became mortal; subject to sin and death, and were unable to return to Heavenly Father without his help. They could now experience disease and all types of suffering. They had moral agency, or the ability to choose between good and evil, which made it possible for them to learn and progress. It also made it possible for them to make wrong choices and to sin. In addition, they could now have children, so the rest of God’s spirit children could come to Earth, obtain physical bodies, and be proven. All this was in accordance with the plan of God. Only in this way could God's children progress and become like him.<ref>http://www.lds.org {{specify|date=December 2010}}</ref>
